title: 111_s657
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sunshine in the Courtroom Act of 2009". It pertains to federal appellate and district courts. The term "presiding judge" in this section refers to the judge overseeing the court proceeding, with specific criteria for different types of courts. The term "Appellate court of the United States" is also defined. The presiding judge of an appellate court of the United States may allow media coverage of court proceedings, including photographing, recording, broadcasting, or televising, at their discretion. Exceptions apply in certain cases. The presiding judge of a district court in the United States has the authority to determine if an action would violate the due process rights of any party in a proceeding. This power is granted regardless of other laws, with exceptions noted. The presiding judge of a district court in the United States may allow the photographing, recording, broadcasting, or televising of court proceedings, with the option to obscure the face and voice of witnesses upon request. The presiding judge may allow the broadcasting of court proceedings but must inform non-party witnesses of their right to request their image and voice to be obscured during testimony. The judge cannot take this action if it violates due process rights. The presiding judge has discretion to obscure the face and voice of an individual in court proceedings if there is good cause to believe that it would threaten the safety of the individual. No media coverage of jurors is allowed during trial proceedings or jury selection. The presiding judge has discretion to obscure the face and voice of an individual in court proceedings to protect safety, court security, law enforcement operations, or the interest of justice. The authority for this provision will end 3 years after the enactment of the Act. Interlocutory appeals challenging the judge's decision on media coverage are not allowed. The Judicial Conference of the United States may establish advisory guidelines for court proceedings. The United States may issue advisory guidelines for judges to consider when deciding on media coverage in court proceedings. Within 6 months of the Act's enactment, mandatory guidelines must be established for judges to follow in obscuring the identities of vulnerable witnesses. The guidelines for court proceedings include procedures for identifying vulnerable witnesses and the presiding judge has discretion to set rules for media use in the courtroom. Written acknowledgment of the rules may be required before acquiring any images or sounds from the courtroom. The guidelines for court proceedings include procedures for identifying vulnerable witnesses and the presiding judge has discretion to set rules for media use in the courtroom. No audio pickup or broadcast of conferences between attorneys and clients is allowed. Expenses for accommodations related to this Act may be required without public expense. The court retains inherent authority to protect witnesses, maintain decorum, and ensure safety.
